title: Lipoma vs. Liposarcoma
diagnosis_topic: Evaluation of a benign subcutaneous mass with consideration of malignancy
setup_script: A 45-year-old woman presents with a soft, mobile mass on her upper arm that she noticed two years ago. It has grown slowly and is now about 5 cm in diameter.

dynamic_flow.reply: Soft, rubbery, mobile under the skin, non-tender; overlying skin normal.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident asks about growth rate and symptoms
dynamic_flow.reply: Growth has been slow; no pain or weight loss.
Shows a homogeneous, hypoechoic, well-circumscribed lesion consistent with lipoma.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident considers MRI for lesions >5 cm or deep
dynamic_flow.reply: MRI reveals well-encapsulated mass without invasion.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident differentiates lipoma from liposarcoma
dynamic_flow.reply: Liposarcoma often larger, deep, firm, rapidly growing or associated with pain; biopsy indicated if suspicious.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident recommends no further workup for benign lesion
dynamic_flow.reply: Observation appropriate if asymptomatic; reassure patient.
Discuss local excision under local anesthesia for symptomatic relief or cosmetic reasons.
Mass removed and pathology confirms benign lipoma.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident provides postoperative care instructions
dynamic_flow.reply: Keep incision clean and dry; monitor for recurrence.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident evaluates for multiple lipomas
dynamic_flow.reply: Consider familial multiple lipomatosis; genetic counseling if significant.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident advises patient to return for changes
dynamic_flow.reply: Encourage reporting of rapid growth, firmness or pain suggesting malignancy.

critical_decision_points: Clinical evaluation of subcutaneous masses including size, depth and consistency
Appropriate use of imaging and biopsy for suspicious lesions
Differentiating benign lipoma from liposarcoma based on features
Patient counseling on monitoring and recurrence
